title: 112_hr31
content: The Act is titled the "Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Accountability and Transparency for Taxpayers Act of 2011." It requires quarterly reports during conservatorship. The Inspector General of the Federal Housing Finance Agency must submit reports to Congress summarizing activities and conditions of each enterprise during a reporting period. Reports must include details on liabilities, risks to the Federal Government, and changes from previous periods. During the reporting period, the enterprise must provide an explanation of compensation and bonuses paid to executive officers, retention decisions made, and details of foreclosure mitigation activities, including approved law firms and eligibility criteria. During the reporting period, the enterprise must provide details on mortgage loans refinanced through foreclosure mitigation activities, mortgage fraud prevention efforts, and communication with Governors and Board staff. During the reporting period, the enterprise must disclose communication with Governors and Board staff, investments inconsistent with its mission, and reasons for equity investments by the Department of the Treasury. An analysis of the enterprise's capital levels, portfolio size, and underwriting standards for mortgage loans, as well as actions affecting securities holders, including preferred stock issued before September 6, 2008. Additionally, any other relevant information requested by the Inspector General. The Inspector General may request any relevant information regarding the enterprise, its activities, and condition. Reporting periods for each enterprise include an initial period from the start of conservatorship to the enactment of the Act, with subsequent quarterly reports. The reporting periods for each enterprise vary depending on the situation. For regular operations, reports are due quarterly within 60 days after the end of the period. However, if a receiver is appointed, reports are due monthly within 30 days after the end of the period. If the Federal Government or its agencies take control of an enterprise, reporting periods will be 6-month periods starting from the nationalization, with reports due within 60 days after each period. The Inspector General will make information on activities public. The Inspector General will make information on activities public, including reports submitted to Congress, through a Federal Housing Finance Agency website. They will also establish contact methods for the public to report waste, fraud, or abuse. Definitions for terms like "conservatorship period" are provided in this section. The term "enterprise" refers to the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The reporting period is defined as a specific timeframe mentioned in subsection (c). The Inspector General of the Federal Housing Finance Agency is established. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1992 is amended to include a new subsection (d) establishing an Inspector General within the Agency with direct hire authority for appointments in the Office of the Inspector General. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1992 is amended to establish an Inspector General within the Agency with direct hire authority for appointments in the Office of the Inspector General, effective for a 12-month period after the enactment of the Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Accountability and Transparency for Taxpayers Act of 2011. Dual compensation waiver authority is granted, subject to certain conditions and exceptions. An annuitant receiving an annuity from the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund can continue to receive their annuity without termination or offset if they become employed in a position within the Office of the Inspector General of the Agency. They will not be considered an employee for certain purposes under title 5, United States Code. The Office of the Inspector General of the Agency has law enforcement authority and is exempt from initial determination of eligibility by the Attorney General under the Inspector General Act of 1978.
